Author: jl777c#5810

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it didnt crash and recovered from that, it is very good

Content: Yeah, 3k+ on each.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: 10 limit isn't it?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is virtually no mem allocation going on, most of the memory is statically crated

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: hashtables in a single second is a fixed size. if you exceed it, it wont fit any more and prints some errors

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: 64gb mem on this node.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: will try the same on smaller node and check memory usage.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you filled up the hashtable for one of the seconds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it printed that the hashtable was full

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not sure what the mystery is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: did it crash?

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: No, not a mystery.  Worked and recovered well.

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: I read that as  DO IT AGAIN!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this system uses a best efforts method, like UDP

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you go too fast, it is too fast and it wont be able to process all of it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: packets will be dropped in hopes that the node can stay caught up after dropping packets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the idea is that there are types of data where it isnt a big deal (maybe annoying) and not going to lose funds even if all the data doesnt get to everyone all the time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for such types of data, this is a good solution

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if losing even a single packet is a disaster, them this is not the proper system to use, we have plenty of lossless blockchains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and these are not transactions, though nothing prevents the datablobs from being actual transactions

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Yes, it worked well.  I'm curious to see how the smaller vps will perform.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, that is a good test

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: my small nodes are doing perfectly fine, until it goes above their limit, which seems to be 3k/sec for one of the 10 nodes. at that point, it gradually loses ground until it is hopelessly behind

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: some networks just wont be able to handle 3k/sec

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: So... with a sinlge node online... should I be trying anything other than seeing how many blasters I can run?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a single node isnt testing much, need at least 2 nodes

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: what would you say are absolute mins epcs for a VM?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: whatever can run a komodod

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without a blockchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: + 1GB RAM

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is all RAM based, HDD doesnt matter

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless not enough RAM and you need to use swap

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: K lets play the resource game then... ill spin up a few and see what can be done with a tiny build

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the CPU and bandwidth will be the limiting factor and even small node can handle 3k/sec, just not 10k/sec

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content:
Ubuntu 18.04 LTS states minimum as:

2 GHz dual core processor or better
2 GB system memory
25 GB of free hard drive space

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you had enough swap to be able to build the komodod, that would be enough to run the node at full speed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is all RAM based and very fast
